captions.text: When people say:

"When you sit in a chair like
I'm sitting in this chair right now"
"I'm actually hovering over this chair"

"but actually my butt is hovering
above the chair by this

just tiny tiny amout"
"because of the electrons of my body"

"because the electrons of my butt"
"are repelling the electrons of this chair"

"it's not us actually touching the subatomic
material of the object"

Is that really true? Does it mean that MC Hammer
has just been singing about physics all along?
"Can't touch this !!"

Alas, this doesn't take into account the fact
that the universe is quantum mechanical

For example, you probably know that electrons
behave like spread-out waves
and from chemistry, you probably also know

that it's perfectly fine for two
negatively charged electrons

to share the same energy level
of an atom or a molecule

as long as they have their intrinsic spins
oriented in opposite directions
So, even though electrons repel each other
their wave packets can overlap.

For example, check out this image
of a ring of iron atoms
sitting on a surface of copper.

see the overlap of the spread out electrons?
Now, would you call that touching?

If you look at a dictionnary,
touch is usually defined

as physical contact.
Well, contact is defined as

touching physically.
Not much help.

But most of people have
this intuitive idea that

touch is something like two
solid objects

so close together
there is no space between them.

The trouble is this doesn't have
anything to do with overlapping

waves which, as we know,
are how electrons actually behave.

So, it seems that touch
is a word that may just be

incapable of describing the actual
universe as we understand it today.

Either that, or we should 
change our notion of touch

to mean interaction at short distance
which is really what happens
between electrons when you sit on a chair.

But, regardless of whether 
or not we ever actually touch anything

I think that when we talk about
the electromagnetic repulsion

of your butt and your chair,
what we are really trying to say is

Hey! Remember how cool it is
that we are made of atoms and molecules

and that other people
made of atoms and molecules

were clever enough 
to figure that out.
Now, that is touching.

This episode of Minute Physics
is supported by audible.com

The leading provider of audio books
across all types of litterature
including fiction, non-fiction and periodicals

I highly recommend
'Surely you're joking, Mr. Feynman'

A hilarious and fascinating
autobiography

of the amazing man and physicist
Richard Feynman

and you can download this audiobook
or another of your choice for free
at audible.com/minutephysics

Again, thanks to Audible
for making it possible for me

to keep producing Minute Physics
and for giving you a free audiobook
at audible.com/minutephysics

Believe it or not, when I was really young before I had even heard of 
atoms, probably when I was around six, I wondered if when I touched my two 
fingers together if they were really touching or if there was a small 
amount of space in between that, which couldn't be filled. I also wondered 
if there was a smallest distance in the universe, and I had all kinds of 
other questions I didn't even know how to articulate, but now have been 
answered to me though knowledge of physics. Did anyone else wonder about 
things when you were really young like that?﻿

No, when you rub the graphite on paper, the friction causes the graphite to

comments.author: agent475816

comments.text:
Again, no. The electrons of the graphite and paper interact at a distance 
with photons, as always. However, there is a slight attraction between the 
graphite and paper molecules which "pulls" on the graphite and "sticks" it 
to the paper. Everything is held together with intermolecular forces; the 
electrons and nuclei never actually touch anything.

comments.text:
every microscopic particle has a wave-particle duality.
Joseph louis deBroglie  hypothesized this after he looked at two sides of 
the same coin (einstein proposing light to be discrete-quanta and huygens 
with his wave theory)
deBroglie put the two together and came up with an equation lambda=h/mv 
where lambda is the wavelength.
this equation tells us EVERYTHING in the physical world behaves as a 
wave..the wave characteristic of objects is better observed when the object 
has a high enough velocity and mass...electrons though with low masses have 
very high velocities..so their wave characteristics are more pronounced 
even though they're particles.So,everything we see has a wave-particle 
duality.
for an apt description of the quanta,read a book called 'quantum' by Manjit 
Kumar

comments.author: Lunick Martins

comments.text:
The sensation of feeling IS the interaction of molecules/electrons 
(whatever) with each other. 
I know what you are trying to ask but in the video it is said that the word 
touch is not really capable of describing the occuring physical phonomena 
sufficiently.
Touching is, if you will, 'a gap' between two atoms (I'm not really happy 
with this picture but it's extremely hard to find the right words to 
describe it accurately). If two atoms are approaching each other, before 
they are repelling each other, they are attracting each other 
(Van-der-Waals-Forces). At a specific distance from each other they start 
repelling, so if the attracting force and the repelling force balance out, 
the atoms are, per definition, touching.
The only really problem here is actually the definition of what you define 
as "touch"

comments.author: Fespie

comments.text:
Though we may be applying what feels like only horizontal force with our 
fingers when we pick something up to try and lift it, we are in fact, 
applying an upward force as well. There are small variations in the surface 
of our fingers and the surface of the object we are trying to pick. When in 
contact, some of the variations of your finger that are horizontal or 
slanted touch a corresponding horizontal or slanted surface such that when 
you lift your hand the repulsive force of the electrons pushes on these 
variations in the upward direction.
